column4: hello... is there a way for me to see from what repository a package came?
hmm... "apt-cache policy libqtcore4" tells me the package version... but not the actual repository it came from (http://rafb.net/p/yHNdwa13.html)

What's bugging me is that I believe I've removed all the non-standard repositories from sources.list but this package (libqtcore4) is still under "installed packages" and not "obsolete and locally inserted"

no, you're right, it doesn't. i don't believe anything does, apt-cache just comes close, by giving you a list of repositories the package is found in (in this case, it isn't even telling you the repository, probably because the package isn't there anymore)
all odds are that that package comes from the KDE4 PPA repository
and I need to downgrade it (and all its dependencies) to the official repo so I can install libqt4-dev
i'm afraid you'll have to do them manually
ok... well I had that repo... but I've commented it out, updated and it's still in "installed" as opposed to "obsolete and locally installed"
you can install a specific version of a package with sudo apt-get install packagename=version
ahhhh... a package goes to obsolete only if it's not found in any other repo
right... I'll try that but I'm just a little worried about dependency problems when going that way
yes, you're likely to have dependency issues that will have to be solved painfully
thing is though... I created an /etc/apt/preferences file that put a high priority on the o=Ubuntu... but I guess that's not enough... :(
anyways... gotta run to class now... thanks so much for your help
sorry, i really don't quite understand APT pinning and all that
you could use some ugly command like this to find out what packages come from the ppa repositories...  pt-cache search "" | xargs -n 1 apt-cache policy | grep ppa
or, you find out how to do it from aptitude in some cleaner way
